entry.title: Re: User ID for IAS users
entry.content:
Hello @dyaryura , @MatthiasL,

Thank you for your reply.

I have a quick question: Why shouldn’t we use the employee ID as the key attribute? The employee ID is unique for everyone.

Are there any problems or technical reasons not to use it—especially since it comes from a trusted source like Entra ID?

Also, can I use the following transformation to set employeeId as the Global User ID or is that not recommended?

Source Transformation ( Entra ID):
{
"sourcePath": "$.employeeId",
"optional": true,
"targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']"
}

Target Transformation (IAS):
{
"sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']",
"optional": true,
"targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['userUuid']"
}

Many Thanks in advance.

Best regards

entry.title: Re: Batch Specific UoM conversion functionality not worki...
entry.content:
Some of the potential root causes beyond Configuration

1. Incorrect Characteristic Value Interpretation
Even if the characteristic BASE_M_TO_CONV_PC is correctly maintained, SAP might be misinterpreting it due to decimal format issues (e.g., 5.5 being read as 2.75 due to localization settings or rounding logic). Unit conversion factor misalignment in the material master or class assignment. Check the internal table values during GR posting (e.g., via debugging or transaction MB51) to see what conversion factor is being picked up.

2. Batch Class Assignment Conflict
If multiple classes are assigned or if the batch class is not properly linked to the material. SAP may default to a fallback conversion or ignore the batch-specific value. Use CL30N to confirm that the batch class is uniquely assigned and active for the material.

3. GR Posting via MIGO vs. Other Transactions
Sometimes, the behavior differs depending on whether you're posting via MIGO, CO11N, MB1A / MB31. Test the same batch in different posting transactions to see if the issue is transaction-specific.

4. Recent System Patch or Note Implementation
If this issue started suddenly, it’s possible that a support package or SAP Note was applied that altered the conversion logic. A custom enhancement or BAdI was introduced or modified. Check with your BASIS or ABAP team for recent transports or OSS notes applied in the system.

One diagnostic suggestion from my side to isolate the issue:

  • Create a test material with a simplified setup (one batch, one class, one characteristic).
  • Post a GR for 10 PC and observe the base UoM conversion.
  • If it works correctly, the issue is likely data-specific or enhancement-related.

entry.title: Re: partially committed webservice-transactions in SQL An...
entry.content:
> So you want an LOAD TABLE that just loads whatever data it can?

No, exactly the opposite: Unless I make use of the optional ALLOW n/ALL ERRORS clause, I want the whole LOAD TABLE statement to rollback on errors.
My tests with LOAD TABLE into local temporary tables with NOT TRANSACTIONAL however have shown, that even without the ALLOW ... ERRORS clause, if a row could not be loaded (say, because of RI or data-type errors) and an error was thrown, the already loaded rows would still remain in the table. I have raised that as a question monthes ago but it's not a current problem I have to face. It was mostly a surprising behaviour.

entry.title: Realizing AI’s Potential in and Through SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Realizing AI’s Potential in and Through SAP Integration Suite 

AI is reshaping how enterprises approach integration, simplifying complex processes, reducing manual effort, and unlocking new levels of agility. In SAP Integration Suite, AI is more than just a trend: it is both a set of powerful capabilities enhancing integration today, and a key enabler for intelligent, connected systems in the future.  

  • AI in Integration Suite – Intelligence is embedded directly into the product to enhance developer productivity, improve operational efficiency, and accelerate time to cloud through features like flow generation and optimization, anomaly detection, and intelligent troubleshooting and monitoring. 
  • Integration Suite for AI – SAP Integration Suite also plays a vital role in enabling next-generation AI scenarios. It acts as the integration foundation for orchestrating autonomous, context-aware agents and supporting seamless interaction between AI systems and enterprise landscapes, backed by the governance and scalability that modern businesses need. 

This blog offers a practical overview of SAP Integration Suite’s evolving AI capabilities, highlighting how AI is embedded in SAP Integration Suite today, how it maps to key integration needs, and how it enables customers to build toward an AI-augmented future. 

 

AI in Integration Suite: Embedded Intelligence in Action

AI is not an isolated feature in SAP Integration Suite, instead, it’s woven into the platform to enhance how integrations are designed, built, and operated. Our embedded AI capabilities focus on delivering real, day-to-day value across two core dimensions: 

  • Improve developer productivity
  • Enhance operational excellence

Here’s how embedded intelligence is making an impact in these areas: 

Improve Developer Productivity 

Designing integrations can be time-consuming, especially when dealing with complex mappings, unfamiliar systems, or writing custom scripts to handle specific logic. SAP Integration Suite embeds AI to streamline this process and help developers move faster with greater confidence. 

  • iFlow Creation
    Developers can now generate integration flows simply by describing the scenario in natural language. This generative AI capability interprets the intent, assembles a draft iFlow with relevant flow steps, and gives developers a strong starting point, and significantly accelerating the design phase. Future enhancements are expected to include automatic generation of mappings, scripts, and other artifacts to further streamline the process. Check the roadmap for new updates. 

 

  • Script Optimization
    Generative AI in SAP Integration Suite can help developers refine Groovy and JavaScript scripts by analyzing code in real time and suggesting best-practice optimizations. These recommendations reduce the need for manual tuning, streamline the coding process and help maintain high performance and quality from the outset.
  • Integration Advisor
    Integration Suite is one of the first iPaaS to embed AI into capabilities for supporting B2B scenarios. Integration Advisor uses a machine learning-based, global knowledge pool to propose mappings between source and target structures. By learning from industry standards and past implementations, it dramatically reduces the time and effort required to configure B2B and A2A integrations, especially in complex message transformation scenarios.
  • Flow Step Recommendations
    When developers build integration flows, AI recommends the next logical flow step, such as a Groovy script or End Message, based on usage patterns. This intelligent guidance accelerates the flow creation process, minimizes trial-and-error, and supports consistent design quality across teams.

Together, these capabilities significantly reduce repetitive tasks, speed up development, and help teams deliver high-quality integrations more efficiently, regardless of their experience level. 

 

Enhance Operational Excellence 

Operational reliability is critical for scalable, enterprise-grade integration. SAP Integration Suite embeds AI to help teams proactively monitor, maintain, and optimize their integration landscapes, reducing manual troubleshooting and improving long-term performance. 

  • API Anomaly Detection 
    Leveraging machine learning, the platform continuously monitors integration flows and APIs to detect unusual patterns, such as latency spikes, increased error rates, or unexpected traffic surges. This helps teams identify and address issues before they impact business processes, improving response time and reducing downtime. 

 

  • API Volume Prediction
    AI models analyze historical usage patterns to forecast, providing two distinct insights: one on historical usage trends and the other on predicted future volumes. The dual view helps developers and operations teams stay ahead of peak loads and avoid capacity-related disruptions, ensuring both long-term planning and real-time operational awareness.
  • Script Optimization
    Generative AI analyzes custom Groovy or JavaScript scripts used in integration flows, identifying potential performance bottlenecks or inefficiencies. It then recommends optimized versions of the code, enabling developers to improve execution quality without deep manual debugging or rewriting.

By embedding these intelligent capabilities, SAP Integration Suite supports a more proactive, data-driven approach to integration operations, allowing teams to deliver higher reliability with less overhead. 

 

Integration Suite for AI: Enabling the Next Generation of Intelligent Automation

As the enterprise landscape evolves, agentic AI is emerging as a new class of autonomous systems that can reason, interact, and execute tasks on behalf of users. This shift is driving demand for more adaptable and intelligent integration backbones. To function effectively, these AI agents must be able to connect with enterprise systems, orchestrate business logic, access data, and execute workflows securely and reliably. This is where SAP Integration Suite becomes essential. It not only embeds AI to optimize development and operations, but also plays a foundational role in enabling agentic AI by providing the connective fabric that links intelligent agents with business applications and services. 

Across the industry, we’re seeing a growing push toward agent-centric automation, from AI copilots to autonomous digital workers, and integration is the linchpin that determines whether these agents can truly act in context. SAP Integration Suite helps enterprises bridge this gap with built-in capabilities that simplify how AI agents discover, consume, and govern enterprise integrations. 

Here are two ways it already supports this shift: 

  • AI Adapter
    The AI Adapter enables seamless communication between SAP Integration Suite and generative AI services, provided by SAP’s AI Core or third-party providers like OpenAI. With minimal configuration, developers can embed AI capabilities, such as text generation, summarization, or classification, directly into integration flows. This makes it easier to enrich payloads with contextual insights, automate decision logic, and integrate AI-driven functionality within a governed framework. By removing the need for custom scripting or API handling, the AI Adapter boosts developer efficiency and expands the scope for advanced AI-powered use cases. 
  • AI-Powered Content Recommendations in Business Accelerator Hub
    To help agents and developers access the right integration assets quickly, the SAP Business Accelerator Hub features Joule for natural language search. Instead of browsing manually, users (or agents in the future) can ask questions like “How do I connect SAP S/4HANA to Salesforce?” and receive tailored recommendations across integration flows, APIs, and templates. This AI-driven discovery process reduces time to integration and enhances reusability, which is the key requirement for agent-based automation where responsiveness and adaptability are critical.

 

Where We’re Heading 

The evolution of AI in SAP Integration Suite is accelerating, expanding beyond foundational productivity and monitoring features into more adaptive, intelligent, and autonomous integration experiences. 

On the embedded AI front, we’re advancing how integrations are designed, optimized, and managed. Expect more powerful capabilities for automating integration development and API operations, along with intelligent migration from legacy systems like SAP Process Orchestration. These innovations are designed to further boost developer efficiency, reduce operational overhead, and reduce time to cloud. 

At the same time, SAP Integration Suite is evolving to support agent-driven automation. As part of this direction, we plan to enhance the API Management to allow AI systems to interact with enterprise tools and data. This will enable more dynamic, context-aware automation, built on a foundation of governance, scalability and future readiness. 

In the upcoming blogs, we’ll explore each of the two directions in depth, highlighting real-world use cases, customer stories, and innovations that are redefining integration in the era of AI.

entry.title: Re: Entry xxxxxxx does not exist in J_1BTXJUR (check entry)
entry.content:
Some key areas to recheck

1. Jurisdiction Code Format
Ensure that the jurisdiction code in your document is exactly formatted as it appears in J_1BTXJUR—no extra spaces, leading zeros, or case mismatches. SAP is strict about matching the internal format of the jurisdiction code.

2. Address Determination Logic
Even though ME23N shows the correct address, SAP might be deriving the jurisdiction code from a different source during invoice posting (e.g., vendor master or plant address). Use transaction SE37 to debug the function module J_1B_GET_JURISDICTION to see how the code is being derived.

3. Missing Link in Configuration
Check if the jurisdiction code is assigned to the correct tax region and tax type in J_1BTXJURT. Also verify that the tax code used in the invoice is linked to the correct jurisdiction group in J_1BTXISS.

4. Document Origin
If the invoice is being posted via MIRO, FB60, or an interface (like IDoc), the jurisdiction code might be missing or malformed in the payload. Use transaction SOST or IDoc monitoring (WE02) to inspect the raw data.

To narrow down the issue, try posting a test invoice manually using FB60 with the same vendor and tax code. If it works, the issue is likely interface-related or data-specific. If it fails, the problem is likely in the jurisdiction setup or derivation logic.

entry.title: Actual Costing in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Actual Costing is available in SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud, public edition) with the scope item 33Q. It valuates all goods movements (procurement, manufacturing, stock transfers, subcontracting, etc.) and collects any incurred variances for your materials within a period and calculates their actual prices, which are usually more accurate than standard prices (S-price) and moving average prices (V-price) in reflecting actual costs of the products.

At period end, the actual prices are also used to revaluate your consumption, e.g. COGS (cost of goods sold), and period-end inventory. Valuation at actual cost is not only helpful but also legally required in some countries/regions as your financial statements, such as Profit & Loss statement and Balance Sheet, can be updated with the actual costing results.

Actual Costing helps you gain real-time insights into business performance and make informed decisions, especially in industries or organization with big fluctuations in raw material prices or volatile production processes.

Now, let’s look at a simplified example to understand how Actual Costing works:

Example Process

In this example, various transactions are involved to demonstrate how price variances are collected from purchase of the lower-level material and production of the finished goods, how the variances are then allocated to cost of sales and remaining inventory, and what revaluation journal entries are posted to reflect the real product profitability.

Let’s walk through each step to see how data is processed in Actual Costing:

 

1. Create a Purchase Order

Company code 1210 has EUR as its local currency (company code currency). The raw material RM124 has a standard price of 0.35 EUR/PC in plant 1210 in period 008/2025 as shown in the material master record below:

A purchase order (4500000253) is created, ordering 100 pieces of RM124 with a net price of 0.50 USD/PC from a foreign supplier.

Note that the total PO price of 50 USD is converted into 40.39 EUR with the exchange rate 1.23794 effective at PO creation. This leads to a price difference of 5.39 EUR between PO price and standard price (40.39 – 35.00 = 5.39 EUR).

2. Receive Goods for the Purchase Order

Following goods receipt of 50 PC of RM124 into inventory, you can see the price difference is collected in the Actual Costing app – Material Price Analysis (CKM3N):

By selecting the goods receipt line and choose Source Document, you will find the price difference of 5.39 EUR is debited as a net loss in a P&L account under transaction key PRD in the Accounting document:

3. Receive Invoice for the Purchase Order

When we receive the invoice for the PO, the exchange rate from USD to EUR has changed to 0.9.

Therefore, the invoice value of 50 USD is converted into 55.56 EUR.

This results in an exchange rate difference of 15.17 EUR (55.56 – 40.39 = 15.17 EUR) debited under transaction key KDM in the Accounting document.

Material Price Analysis (CKM3N) also receives the exchange rate difference in a separate line as below:

4. Create a Production Order

Now that the required raw material RM124 has received into inventory, the plant 1210 is ready to starts its manufacturing of the product SG224-DEMO. For this, a production order (1011288) of 50 PC of SG224-DEMO is created:

According to bill of materials (BOM) and routing of SG224-DEMO, the following raw materials and production activities are required to manufacture 100 PC of SG224-DEMO:

5. Goods Issue, Time Confirmation, and Goods Receipt for the Production Order

In the actual manufacturing process, variances can happen in the consumption of components (input materials) and activities. In  this example, we confirm more working time for activities Setup (activity type 3), Machine (1), and Labor (11) than planned.

Due to the Backflush indicator, with the time confirmation above, the withdrawal (goods issue) of input materials (RM124) is posted automatically.

Since the final operation 0020 has the Automatic Goods Receipt indicator flagged, confirmation of 0020 also results in a full delivery (goods receipt) of 50 PC into inventory.

6. Settle the Production Order

Since 1011288 is an event-based production order, full delivery automatically triggers the order settlement. We can check the production variances in app Order Costs Details - Event-Based:

The total production variance is 407.08 EUR, split into different variance categories, reflecting the causes of the variances. The variance is debited as a net loss in P&L account under transaction key PRD in the Accounting document.

Note: The above-mentioned features are related to Production Accounting (3F0) and are not the main goal of this blog. You can find more details in SAP help (https://help.sap.com/s4_ce_prd_acc).

Now we can look at how the goods receipt and production variance of SG224-DEMO is captured in Material Price Analysis (CKM3N):

  • Goods receipt of 50 PC is evaluation as 341.00 EUR (50 PC multiplied by standard price 6.82 EUR) as shown in Preliminary Valuation column.
  • The production variance of 407.08 EUR collected from order settlement is shown as Price Difference.

7. Create a Sales Order and Outbound Delivery

Following the completion of production of SG224-DEMO, we create a sales order (1516) to sell 20 PC of SG224-DEMO at the price 10 EUR/PC to a customer. Then we issue the goods to the customer with an outbound delivery document (80000286):

The goods issue is updated in Material Price Analysis (CKM3N) under Consumption as follows:

Before the actual costing settlement, the sales quantity of 20 PC is still evaluated using standard price 6.82 EUR (6.82 EUR * 20 PC = 136.40 EUR).

Note that the profitability segment 106851 is derived from the sales order item. It combines all the relevant attributes of the sales order, including sales order ID, sales org, distribution channel, customer group, ship-to party, etc.

8. Settlement in Actual Costing

At the period-end close, we execute the Actual Costing run in CKMLCP (Edit Actual Costing Run), also known as costing cockpit.

Note: Before the settlement in Actual Costing, make sure you’ve run the WIP Quantity Calculation job in Schedule Inventory Accounting Jobs for accurate WIP revaluation in Actual Costing. Also, remember to calculate actual activity cost rates in the Actual Cost Rate Calculation - Cost Centers app. These steps are not demonstrated in this example.

In the settlement step, the system does the following:

1. Determine any price and exchange rate variances of lower-level materials (RM124 in our example).

In the Cumulative Inventory line, Actual Value (90.56 EUR) is a sum of preliminary valuation value, price difference and exchange rate difference. The actual price 0.45 EUR/PC of RM124 by dividing the actual value (90.56 EUR) by the cumulative quantity (200 PC).

Note that according to the ratio of consumption quantity/cumulative quantity (50 PC/200 PC), the production of SG224-DEMO only shares 1/4 of the total difference (5.39 EUR + 15.17 EUR = 20.56 EUR), that is 5.14 EUR (20.56 EUR/4). 

2. Roll the variances through to higher materials (SG224-DEMO) that used the lower-level materials.

In Material  Price Analysis of finished goods SG224-DEMO, 5.14 EUR from lower material (RM124) is rolled up, divided into 1.35 EUR of price difference and 3.79 EUR of exchange rate difference.

3. Calculate actual price (periodic unit price).

Actual price is calculated for each of the materials as shown above: 0.45 EUR/PC for RM124 and 15.06 EUR/PC for SG224-DEMO. These prices can reflect the actual cost more accurately, as all goods movements and cost fluctuations within the period are considered.

4. Allocate the cumulated variance (and cumulative actual value) to consumption and ending inventory.

As shown in screenshots of points 1 and 2, the cumulative differences are allocated to consumption and ending inventory in proportion to the quantity as follows:

MaterialCumulative Difference (EUR)Consumption (EUR)Ending Inventory (EUR)
RM12420.56 (= 5.39+15.17)5.14 (=20.56*1/4)15.42 (=20.56*3/4)
SG224-DEMO412.22 (=408.43+3.79)164.89 (=412.22*2/5)247.33 (=412.22*3/5)

With that, consumption and ending inventory are revaluated as shown in Actual Value column.

9. Post Closing Documents

Now that the cumulative differences are allocated and actual values of consumption and inventory are revaluated, we can post the closing entries to ACDOCA (Universal Journal) to adjust the consumption (e.g. COGS for SG224-DEMO) and ending inventory values, so that the relevant P&L accounts and B/S accounts are updated.

To do that, select both Revaluate Material and Revaluate Consumption when executing Post Closing in the costing cockpit (CKMLCP),

The Post Closing step is executed successfully.

In Material Price Analysis, you don’t see much changes except the Period Status is updated to Closing Entries Completed and the price control of the materials is converted from S (Standard Price) to V (Periodic Unit Price), meaning the material stock has been revaluated at the actual PUP price in the period.

Taking SG224-DEMO as an example, let’s look at what closing journal entries are posted by Actual Costing (you can jump to these journal entries by choosing Closing Document on the screen). These journal entries are classified with the type ML (ML Settlement). ML stands for Material Ledger and Actual Costing is traditionally a part of it.

In the consumption (COGS) revaluation journal entry 4700000034, we can see that the adjustment value of 164.89 EUR together with the COGS splits by cost component. Notice the Account Assignment Type is EO (Profitability Segment). With the profitability segment 106851, as we saw earlier in the consumption line, the sales order item-specific attributes, such as Product Sold, Sales Order, Sales Org, and Customer, are also kept in the line items. Thanks to that, we can get a margin analysis report with the finest granularity to be shared later.

In the other journal entry 4700000034, by filtering product SG224-DEMO, we can see the following items sorted by transaction key:

  • BSX (Inventory)

Item 44 is a total difference (price and exchange rate differences) of 247.33 EUR is debited to the inventory account, indicating a value increase of the material stock.

  • GBB (COGS)

Item 47 shows a total difference (price and exchange rate differences) of 164.89 EUR is debited to the COGS account.

  • KDM (Exchange Rate Differences)

Items 11 is the exchange rate differences received from lower material RM124. Items 46 and 49 are those credited to the exchange rate difference accounts.

  • PRY (Price Difference)

Item 10 is the price difference received from lower material RM124. Items 45 and 48 are those credited to the difference accounts.

Additionally, the items 44, 46 and 45, representing inventory revaluation line in CKM3N, are automatically reversed in the subsequent period (009/2025) as shown below:

This brings the stock of period 009/2025 back to standard price. Meanwhile, the price differences and exchange rate differences assigned to ending inventory in period 008/2025 are carried over into the beginning inventory of period 009/2025.

In this way, the system ensures the actual cost of the beginning inventory of the new period equal that of the ending inventory of the previous period.

Note: Price difference for the consumption of 164.87 EUR in period 008/2025 is not reversed.

That concludes the example showing how Actual Costing collects differences of all goods movements along the period, calculates a more reliable actual price, and allocates the differences into consumption and material stock.

10. View Produce Profitability

Following the posting of consumption revaluation, you can view updated COGS in margin analysis report, such as Product Profitability Review Booklet:

Here, for 20 PC of the product SG224-DEMO sold, the total COGS 301.29 EUR is a sum of preliminary valuation (136.40 EUR) and the consumption revaluation (163.37 EUR) by Actual Costing as you can see from the CKM3N screen in step 8.

By navigating to the line items, we can confirm that the closing journal entries posted by Actual Costing are considered in the COGS. 

Additional Features

This section briefly talks about the Actual Costing features that are not covered above.

Multiple Currencies and Valuations

Actual Costing supports inventory valuation in multiple currency types (company code currency, group currency, and if configured, functional currency) and valuation views (legal valuation, group valuation) achieved by parallel ledgers.

Valuated Quantity Structure

Valuated quantity structure shows the scaled receipt quantity of the actual input materials/activities in a hierarchical view.

The following screen shows the production structure of SG2024-DEMO from the above example, including raw materials and activity types valuated in both preliminary valuation and actual valuation.

The valuated quantity structure helps you analyze the differences roll-ups by showing all the price differences from the lower level to the top material level.

Note this view is dynamically generated without persisting in database, therefore the system performance might be slow in case of many hierarchy levels.

Cost Component Split (CCS)

Cost component split breaks down costs into cost components such as material, various production activities, and overheads. Actual Costing shares the same cost component structure as in product cost planning.

As you can see in Material Price Analysis, the columns such as Direct Material, Material Overhead, Personnel Time, Machine Time, Set-up Time, and Production Overhead represent the cost components. Their values are determined based on the G/L accounts (cost elements) assigned to each component.

SAP is re-designing the cost component split feature with the concept of Universal Component Breakdown. We will explain this feature in detail when available in Actual Costing.  

Activity Consumption Analysis (CKM3A)

Actual Costing also revaluates activity types of each cost center by using the actual cost rates that are determined in Actual Cost Rate Calculation - Cost Centers  app (KSII).

In the following screen of Activity Consumption Analysis (CKM3A), we can tell that for in plant 1210 in period 008/2025, the cost center 12101301 consumes 1.25 hours of activity type 3 (Setup Production) for manufacturing SG224-DEMO with production order 1011288. In reality, there are more production orders and manufactured products.

The Preliminary Valuation column shows the activity valued with plan cost rates (378.88 EUR/hour) maintained in Manage Cost Rates – Plan or imported from SAP Analytics Cloud. The Actual Value column shows the activity cost valuated at the actual cost rates (388.89 EUR/hour) calculated in KSII at period end.

In the closing journal entries, the price difference is credited to the cost center (transaction key PRL Activity Price Difference)  and debited to the material price account.

Other Fiori Apps

Additional Fiori apps are available for multiple-material view, for example, Display Actual Costing Result F6073. See help documentation for more info.

Technical Implementation:

To use Actual Costing in SAP Cloud ERP, the scope item 33Q must be activated. With 33Q activation, the following are active by default for the relevant plants:

  • Actual cost component split
  • WIP revaluation at actual costs
  • Activity consumption update in actual quantity structure is active and is taken into account upon price determination. 

To access the relevant apps, users must be assigned with a role that contains the following business catalogs:

  • SAP_FIN_BC_IA_AC_PER_ACT_PC (Actual Costing - Periodic Activities) for apps such as Edit Actual Costing Run (CKMLCP).
  • SAP_FIN_BC_IA_FACT_MPRC_PC (Inventory Accounting - Material Price Analysis) for apps such as Material Price Analysis (CKM3N, aka CKM3)
  • SAP_FIN_BC_IA_AC_REP_PC (Actual Costing - Reporting) for apps such as Display Actual Costing Result (F6073).
  • SAP_FIN_BC_IA_OM_REP_PC (Actual Costing - Activity Reporting) for apps such as Activity Consumption Analysis (CKM3A)

Master Data Preparation

The materials subject to Actual Costing settlement are those with price control S (standard price)and price determination 3 (single/multi-level) as below:

Note: By default, price determination 2 (Transaction-Based) is used in material creation.

Related Info

For more deep-dive topics in Actual Costing, for example, WIP revaluation, not distributed and not allocated values, see FAQ Note https://me.sap.com/notes/3617837 (FAQ of Actual Costing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud) with concrete examples.

We will continuously update the Note or publish blogs for other in-depth topics in Actual Costing, such as fallback logic for actual price calculation, account determination for closing journal entries, and available configuration activities. You are very welcome to leave comments under the blog.

entry.title: Re: partially committed webservice-transactions in SQL An...
entry.content:
@Baron, my previous comment was directed to John's comment. Remember a working forum with nested comments? (And where a comment wasn't restrained to an one-line input field? Sigh.

To your latest question on procedures with several result sets: AFAIK, no, it's a different behaviour: SQL Anywhere waits for the client to consume the first result set, and will wait for a "resume" request (*) to provide the next result set, and so on.  (That's different from MS SQL Server or ASE.) But when the client has consumed the last result set, any following statements within the procedure's body are still executed. 

In my understanding, a web service procedure however does not execute code after the final select statement at all. (This has been discussed in the very past, certainly with Breck, I don't have a link.)

(*): For example, with ODBC, a SQLMoreResults() call would provice access to the nxt result set, if there is any.

entry.title: Re: New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration
entry.content:
@Abhinav1 The old package has been deprecated yesterday, but this just means that the name of the package and the names of the integration artifacts have been changed, so we just add the term Deprecated to them. According to the deprecation rules, we need to keep the package at least half a year before actually deleting it, we even are not sure if we really will or can delete them, I see a lot of deprecated packages on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub which have been deprecated for a very long time. Anyway, the integration flows still work even if you update the now deprecated package, as said just the names differ. Your scenario-specific integration flows and your Partner Directory entries won't be affected unless you use a script from the script collection in any of your scenario-specific integration flows. In this case, keep the groovy script collection still running as long as you haven't replaced the scripts within the scenario-specific integration flows from global to local. Otherwise, you can simply switch to the new generic flows from the new packages. Your scenarios should run as before. If you use multiple copied packages for supporting multiple sender scenarios, I guess you refer to either XI inbound or IDoc inbound, then you only need to copy the Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Inbound package multiple times and won't create so much waste.

Alex

entry.title: Re: I want to color the SAC input controls according to t...
entry.content:
Hi @ tsuuuu, 

You are correct. CSS lets you style the input control widget globally. To go further (e.g., colour different states: selected, unselected, disabled), you need to combine SAC Analytic Application scripting with CSS class manipulation.

1. In SAC Analytic Applications, each input control is a widget with scripting APIs.

From this you can:

  • Compare against all available members → determine which are unselected.
  • Compare against a filter or a condition → determine which are disabled/unselectable.

 

2. Once you’ve evaluated the state, you can apply CSS classes dynamically to the DOM elements.

 

3. Here are some Best Practices to provide some details.

  • Use Analytic Applications, not Stories à only applications support this scripting + CSS manipulation.
  • Keep lists like disabled values in a model or script variable, so business logic is centralised.
  • Test across browsers; SAC updates can sometimes alter DOM class names, so pin CSS to unique selectors.
  • Consider usability: always provide a legend explaining your colours.

 

To summarise, you need to combine getSelectedMembers scripting with dynamic CSS injection.

  • Use scripting to evaluate selected, not selected, or disabled/unselectable.
  • Apply CSS classes conditionally to each checkbox option.
  • This way you can achieve green (selected), grey (disabled), none (unselected) colouring for SAC input controls.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Position To Job Sync through Data Loader API creating blank Job Relationship record
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

Scenario:  DATA Loader is being used to update Job Information for employees. While doing a Job information update for an employee (let's say we create a blank data change record in the Job Information with today's date).  After uploading, a blank record gets created in Job Information with Data Change as event reason (AS EXPECTED), but a blank Job relationship record is also getting created with the same effective date.
As per rule trace, the Position to Job Sync rule is getting triggered and e due to the different "Set" Job Relationship Matrix rules, Job Relationship portlet is getting affected and creating blank records even if there no change in Position Matrix relationships.

Is there any workaround where the API profile can be made to identify that this data loader update will only trigger Job Information and not Job Relationship if there is no change in Matrix relationships?

Thanks,
Rigjit Banerjee

entry.title: Re: SQL Anywhere: Problem with JSON data with German umla...
entry.content:
I looked at our JSON parser and it does accept 6-character hex sequences. It should not be doing so and it's a quick fix.

However, I would also recommend that you consider using a CHAR collation based on UTF8 rather than windows-1252. If I recall correctly, sp_parse_json returns its string values as CHAR datatype; however, although our parser internally converts the bare text in strings from NCHAR to CHAR, it explicitly generates UTF8 encoding for escape sequences. The result can be strings that are in a mix of CHAR and UTF8 encoding. It's an old bug but changing our JSON support to use NCHAR everywhere had backward compatibility issues and some other complications that meant it never got implemented. Using a UTF8-based CHAR collation is an easy workaround. Unfortunately, it means a database unload/reload would be required.

entry.title: Re: SAW 17: Question on the system load of file handling functions (xp_write_file, xp_read_file) ?
entry.content:
Files of various sizes, ranging from 500 KB to 20-40 MB, are stored in the database. The average size of a file stored in the database is about 3 MB.

This is a document management database, and document cards are stored in the database (a card consists of a number of fields that are stored in linked tables - master-detail). These document texts are stored in a separate table located in a separate table space in the BLOB field.

Simply put, some users save these document texts to the database, while other users download these document texts from the database to the client's computer for viewing, if necessary.

In this situation, I am interested in the load on the database server in the context of writing/reading these files from (to) BLOB by a large number of users (100-400 simultaneous connections, although not all of these users necessarily view these document texts).

Which is less resource-intensive for the database server: loading these files from the table from the BLOB field or reading them from the file system via xp_read_file and then returning them to the user ?

entry.title: Re: partially committed webservice-transactions in SQL Anywhere
entry.content: @Volker: TEMPORARY NON TRANSACTIONAL tables have not rollback information at all. That's what the "NON TRANSACTIONAL" part is all about. It has nothing to do with LOAD. If you want a LOAD to be all-or-nothing, you cannot use a non-transactional table.

entry.title: Re: FMS In Good Issue
entry.content:
Hi @user2001 ,

This happens because cost centres are bound to the GL in the setting "relevant for cost accounting". BS accounts ideally won't be cost-relevant, so CC fields are "nulled" by SAP. P&L GLs tend to be cost-relevant, so SAP will try to pick the CC from there. If it is null, SAP does the same as the BS, if not, the CC will be pulled from there. 

A workaround would be creating another FMS, assigned to the CC field, so they are cross-dependent:

  1. Keep the Account Code's FMS as is, but change the refresh option to "When Column Value Changes"
  2. Create a new FMS and assign it to your CC field (keep the refresh option to "When Column Value Changes"). It would be something like the below:
SELECT CASE 
    WHEN IFNULL($[$13.59.0], '') = '5001014' THEN 'IDC-1027'
    WHEN IFNULL($[$13.59.0], '') = '5001015' THEN 'IDC-1028'
    ELSE 'XXX-XXXX'
END​

It should do the job.

I hope it helps.

BR,
Felipe

entry.title: How to Prepare for SAP S/4 HANA Private Edition Certification (with Sample Questions)
entry.content:
In this blog, I’ll share practical tips to help you to prepare and be able to pass the SAP S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition certification (E_S4CPE_2405). While the post is especially helpful for those aiming to get certified, it also provides useful insights for SAP developers, Basis Admin, SAP Architects, Project Managers, and anyone who works daily in SAP ERP projects or operations.

You often start preparing for a certification and end up confused or lost, what are the right resources, and how deep should you go through different materials and references?

As a Microsoft and SAP Certified , I always tell new learners: preparing for a certification is like learning English as a second language—you want to be able to use it effectively in your day-to-day work, not become Shakespeare!
Here, I share the exact resources I use in my day-to-day role as an SAP Architect—drawing on over 20 years of hands-on experience in the SAP space. I’ve also included the key materials that can help you confidently prepare for the SAP S/4 HANA Private Edition.

I’ll be updating this post from time to time, since SAP technology and S/4HANA continue to evolve at a fast pace!

Being a successful SAP Solution consultant or SAP Expert requires a deep understanding of both on-premises and hyperscaler technologies, combined with hands-on experience from real customer projects. On top of that, strong expertise in SAP solutions is essential. Earning the SAP S/4 HANA certification is just the beginning of this journey.

This is the second blog of series, I’m going to share practical insights to help you prepare and succeed to achieve this as a goal.

 Why Get SAP Certified? Real-World Benefits:

  • Being certified earns immediate credibility customers, partners, and hiring managers are more likely to trust your knowledge and decisions.
  • SAP certification improves your chances of landing your desired role.
  • Certified professionals often qualify for higher rates, promotions, and leadership roles in SAP projects.
  • In some cases (e.g., security reviews, migration, SOC 2 documentation), certification adds weight to your approval or sign-off.
  • The annual certification renewal process ensures your knowledge stays current, especially with cloud solutions and SAP's evolving product roadmap.
  • Certification validates your hands-on skills and prepares you to deliver better results in real SAP implementations.
  • Certified professionals are more likely to be chosen for challenging or high-impact projects.
  • Certification gives you recognition within the broader SAP ecosystem.

 Exam Topics and Focus Areas
To pass the certification you’ll need a score of 72% or higher, SAP outlines the following key areas:

  • Introduction to Cloud Computing and SAP Cloud ERP Deployment Options (11% - 20%)
  • Data Migration and Business Process Testing (11% - 20%)
  • Implementing with a Cloud Mindset, Building the Team, and Conducting Fit-to-Standard Workshops (11% - 20%)
  • System Landscapes and Identity Access Management (11% - 20%)
  • Configuration and the SAP Fiori Launchpad (11% - 20%)
  • Extensibility, Integration, and Clean Core (11% - 20%)

 Key Areas of Study
To gain the knowledge required, focus on the following areas:

  • Characteristics of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • RISE with SAP Methodology
  • Customer transition paths to SAP S/4 HANA
  • New Implementation (Greenfield)
  • System Conversion (Brownfield)
  • Selective Data Transition (Bluefield)
  • Key Stockholders and their role & responsibilities
  • System landscapes used to implement SAP S/4HANA
  • S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition release upgrade
  • Cloud ALM Implementation Project setup for S/4 HANA
  • System Preparation Activities for conversion
    • Analyse customer’s exiting business process (Signavio)
    • Run and review SAP Readiness check report
  • Identity Access Management in S/4 HANA
    • Creating users in S/4 HANA
    • Business Role vs System Admin Role
    • Fiori Launchpad UI
  • SAP Fiori Launchpad
    • Applications and users
    • Content Manager
    • App Manager
  • Fit-to-Standard analysis workshops (mostly for greenfield customers)
  • Business processes configuration, evaluation , improvement
  • Working with SAP Fiori Launchpad
    • My Home, Spaces and Pages Layout
    • Embedded help support and Joule
    • Ange Team and Responsibilities app
    • Situation Handling
  • Extensibility tools for S/4 HANA
    • Clean core tiers
    • Key user In-App Extensibility
    •  Developer In-App Extensibility
    • Side by Side Extensibility with BTP
  • Setting up integration in S/4 HANA
    • Integration Solution Advisory Methodology
    • Setting up integrations with various recourses
    • Integration Monitoring with Cloud ALM
  • Data migration methods to S/4 HANA
  • Testing types and strategy
    • Cloud ALM for test case and test plan
    • Cloud ALM test Automation (Tricentis)

 Note: All the resources listed below are free. You may only need to create a Universal ID to track your progress if the resource is from SAP Learning Hub.

Recommended (Free) Learning Courses:
Exploring SAP Cloud ERP (Learning Course)

Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition

 Important Reference Links:

 From Classic ABAP to Clean Corse

 ABAP Cloud, Wrappers, and ATC for Stable S/4HANA Upgrades

Introducing the RISE with SAP Methodology for SAP Partners and Customers (Learning Course)

Executing Your Cloud ERP Project (Video)

Specifics of transformation to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Video)

Clean Core - a holistic concept I Move to Cloud ERP (Learning Course)

Managing Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Learning Course)

Explaining Extensibility Model Best Practices (Learning Course)

Clean core extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (Video)

Extensibility Overview and Guidance (Learning Course)

 Advance Learning and Practice
Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Learning Course)

SAP S/4HANA Conversion and SAP System Upgrade (Learning course)

System Conversion to SAP S/4HANA (Learning Course)

Streamline Your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition Upgrade (Video)

Learning the Basics of SAP Fiori (Learning Course)

Getting Started with In-App Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA (Learning Course)

Practicing Clean Core Extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Learning Course)

Building side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP (learning Course)

Develop extensions for SAP S/4HANA with SAP BTP, ABAP Environment, runtime (Mission)

S/4 HANA Fully-Activated Appliance on Hyperscalers  (30 days trail)

S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition free (14 days trail)

Before we start the sample questions , let me explain different types of SAP ERP provisioning.

SAP ECC was traditionally deployed in on-premises environments or customer data centres. With the introduction of S/4HANA, cloud provisioning options became available alongside traditional deployments.

Current Types of SAP ERP Deployment Models

Cloud Editions

  • S/4HANA Cloud, public edition – Multi-tenant SaaS, fully managed by SAP.
  • S/4HANA Cloud, private edition – Single-tenant, SAP-managed infrastructure.

Note: Although it runs on cloud infrastructure, S/4HANA Cloud, private edition shares more operational and management characteristics with on-premises deployments (greater customer control, customization, and lifecycle management).

On-Premises Editions

  • S/4HANA On-Premises in customer data centre – Fully customer-managed.
  • S/4HANA On-Premises managed by SAP (HEC – HANA Enterprise Cloud or ECS-Enterprise Cloud Service) – SAP hosts and operates the system in hyperscalers  on behalf of the customer.
  • S/4HANA On-Premises at hyperscalers – Hosted by AWS, Azure, or Google Cloud but managed by the customer or a systems integrator.
  • S/4HANA On-Premises via SAP certified partners – Deployed using appliances in a customer data centre.
  • S/4HANA for Government (National security Service -NS2 ) – Specialized U.S.  deployment for government and defense, meeting the highest national security certifications in U.S and Canada .

Legacy Options

  • SAP ECC in customer data centre (on-premises) – Classic model, customer-managed.
  • SAP ECC at hyperscalers – Often a transitional step (Unicode migration, system prep) before moving to S/4HANA in cloud environment.

I've put together 15 sample questions to help you prepare for the exam. These questions are a bit more challenging than the ones you'll typically see on the actual test:

Sample Questions

  1. Which choice is the main used of Launchpad Content Manager? There are 2 correct answers to this question
    1. Manage technical catalogs
    2. Create custom business catalogs
    3. Perform mass changes on business catalogs
    4. Add or remove catalogs content references

  2. In an S/4HANA Private Edition implementation, which type of testing focuses on verifying that the overall system still works as expected after applying changes such as upgrades, patches, or configuration updates?
    1. Unit Test
    2. Business Process Test
    3. User Acceptance Test
    4. Regression Test

  3. During an SAP S/4HANA Private Edition project using the SAP Integration Solution Advisory Methodology (ISA-M), which activity would you expect to complete before selecting integration technologies or designing detailed interfaces?
    1. Defining target integration domains and aligning them with business priorities
    2. Establishing governance guidelines for integration domains and setting decision-making processes
    3. Executing end-to-end interface tests with all involved applications
    4. Configuring middleware connections between S/4HANA and third-party systems

  4. A customer is moving from SAP ECC to the latest release of SAP S/4HANA, which will be hosted and managed by the ECS team. Their requirement is to migrate both master data and full historical transactional data into the new environment. Which transition approach would best meet their needs?
    1. System conversion
    2. Select data transition
    3. Lift & shift
    4. Greenfield

  5. How are SAP Best Practices initially deploy in S/4 HANA Cloud Private Edition system?
    1. Through SAP Transport Management
    2. Through SAP Cloud ALM
    3. Through SAP Activate Methodology
    4. Through SAP Solution Builder

  6. A customer running ECC plans to move to SAP S/4HANA Private Edition through a system conversion. They want to follow SAP’s recommended preparation steps to confirm technical readiness, understand functional impacts, and plan for custom code remediation.
    Which of the following sequences reflects SAP’s best practice?
    1. Run the SAP Readiness Check → Review the Simplification Item List → Perform ATC custom code analysis
    2. Perform ATC custom code analysis → Run the SAP Readiness Check → Review the Simplification Item List
    3. Review the Simplification Item List → Run the SAP Readiness Check → Perform ATC custom code analysis
    4. Run the SAP Readiness Check → Perform ATC custom code analysis → Update the Simplification Item List

  7. You are on an SAP S/4HANA Private Edition project where the customer needs to deliver advanced custom business logic that must:
    1.  Reuse internal ABAP application objects (e.g., BAPIs, CDS views) without exposing them via remote APIs first.
    2.   Participate in the same LUW as standard S/4 transactions when required.
    3. Remain upgrade-safe and fully compliant with the “clean core” principle.
    4. Avoid the performance overhead of cross-system remote calls.

           Which approach best meets all of these constraints for a Tier-3 developer extension?

  1. Build the logic in the ABAP environment on SAP BTP (standalone Steampunk) using side-by-side extensions, avoiding any in-stack custom code.
  2. Modify standard ABAP code directly inside S/4HANA to embed the logic within existing processes.
  3. Use SAP Build Apps to deliver the functionality as a low-code/no-code side-by-side extension on SAP BTP.
  4. Develop in the embedded Steampunk ABAP environment inside the S/4HANA system, following in-app extension guidelines and ensuring upgrade safety.

8.  During the Realize phase of an SAP S/4HANA Private Edition project using SAP Activate, the team encounters multiple fit-to-standard gaps that require custom extensions. At the same time, performance issues are found during integration testing, and the customer insists on adding new scope items not originally in the signed backlog.

Which of the following actions are fully aligned with the Activate methodology’s Realize phase best practices? (Select TWO)

  1. Perform configuration in the Quality system based on the backlog items confirmed in the Explore phase and manage any new scope through formal change control.
  2. Re-open Fit-to-Standard workshops to capture and approve all new requirements before continuing configuration.
  3. Conduct performance tuning and regression testing as part of iterative configuration cycles before the formal User Acceptance Test.
  4. Postpone addressing integration performance issues until after cutover, since Realize focuses on functional build.
  5. Implement all new customer scope immediately to avoid delays, updating the backlog informally.

 9. You are in the preparation phase for an SAP S/4HANA Private Edition project and need a platform that provides mission-based guidance, best practices, and ready-to-use service configurations for deploying and extending solutions on SAP BTP. The customer also wants visibility into estimated service costs and technical prerequisites before starting.

        Which SAP platform best meets this need?

  1. SAP Store
  2. SAP Discovery Centre
  3. SAP Business Accelerator Hub
  4. SAP Cloud ALM

10. SAP Cloud ALM You are implementing the latest DMOVE2S4 conversion method (available since SUM 2.0 SP17) for migrating your SAP ECC system from on-premises to hyperscaler cloud. Considering the technical architecture and SUM execution flow, which statements are correct? (Select TWO)

  1. You execute SUM from a newly installed AAS in the target cloud environment, and during the ASCS_ASK phase, SUM automatically detects the remote ASCS instance and offers an "ASCS instance move" dialog to relocate central services to the same target host
  2. You must manually pre-install both AAS and ASCS instances in the target cloud before initiating SUM, ensuring network latency remains below 20ms with minimum 400 MB bandwidth between environments
  3. SUM execution begins from the source PAS while simultaneously creating a shadow AAS instance in the target cloud, with ASCS migration occurring during the EU_CLONE_MNG phase through automated system move protocols
  4. The conversion utilizes standard DMO functionality rather than "DMO with system move," requiring manual post-processing of shared filesystems (/sapmnt/ and /usr/sap/trans) and RFC adjustments after SUM completion

11. In your SAP S/4HANA Private Edition system, you need to manage role maintenance efficiently. Which methods are correct for role management? (Select TWO)

  1. Use transaction PFCG to create roles, assign transactions to menu tree, then generate authorization profiles and perform user master record comparison 
  2. Use transaction SU01 to directly assign authorization profiles to users without generating profiles through role maintenance
  3. Use transaction SU01 to assign users to roles, maintain validity periods, then perform user comparison to activate authorization profiles in user master records
  4. Use Business Role Maintenance Fiori app to create business roles with business catalogs for S/4HANA Private Edition

    12. Which of the following statements correctly describes the Migration Cockpit capabilities and requirements for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations?
  1. Migration Cockpit is a recommended SAP tool that requires separate licensing with dedicated infrastructure setup, exclusively supporting master data migration through manual staging table creation with limited connectivity options
  2. Migration Cockpit is an embedded data migration tool included in S/4HANA licenses that supports both staging tables and direct transfer methods, with value mapping capabilities, simulation features, and comprehensive project management for data migration
  3. Migration Cockpit must be installed and run from the source system with specific add-on requirements, designed exclusively for cloud-to-cloud migrations and cannot support on-premise to private cloud migration scenarios
  4. Migration Cockpit is limited to transactional data migration only and requires mandatory third-party ETL tools for all master data migration scenarios

13. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, when implementing business workflows that require extensive customization capabilities, which of the following statements best describes the workflow development approach available compared to the Public Edition?

  1. Private Edition only supports standard flexible workflows through Central Business Configuration (CBC) similar to Public Edition, with no access to classical workflow development tools.
  2. Private Edition allows full classical ABAP workflow development using SPRO-IMG transactions and Workbench tools, providing the same customization flexibility as S/4HANA On-Premise systems.
  3. Private Edition requires all custom workflows to be developed exclusively on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) with no on-system development capabilities.
  4. Private Edition uses the same starter system approach as Public Edition, where workflows are pre-configured and cannot be modified beyond standard parameters.

14. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, when implementing SAP Best Practices with multiple country solutions in a greenfield environment, which of the following represents the most critical constraint that must be adhered to during the activation process to avoid configuration conflicts and system errors?

  1. SAP Best Practices can only be activated in client 000 as it serves as the reference client, and all country solutions must be activated sequentially starting with the home country before adding international localizations.
  2. Demo data must be activated for all country solutions simultaneously during the initial activation cycle, as it cannot be transported between development, quality, and production systems via standard transport mechanisms.
  3. Once you activate additional scope items or country solutions, you cannot perform any technical upgrade to the next Feature Package Stack (FPS) or new release, and you must not change the SAP Best Practices configuration for already activated countries/regions.
  4. The group currency can be changed at any time during the activation process, and each country solution can maintain its own local currency independent of the global group currency setting.

15. You are modernizing your ECC system by migrating to S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. What would be the most cost-effective and secure approach to enable external users (who do not exist in your corporate Identity Provider) to access S/4HANA applications?

  1. Configure their external IdP as a Corporate Identity Provider in SAP IAS and use SAP RISE external Load Balancer to access S/4HANA embedded Fiori applications
  2. Configure their external IdP as a Corporate Identity Provider in SAP IAS and use SAP Build Work Zone to provide Fiori access to S/4HANA via federation
  3. Create individual VPN connections for each external user to access the corporate network, then leverage RISE internal Load Balancer to connect to S/4HANA
  4. Create individual user accounts in IAS and configure conditional authentication in the S/4HANA application within IAS to direct users to S/4HANA embedded Fiori

Answers:
1. Answer: b, d
The Launchpad Content Manager is specifically designed to manage business catalogs, not technical catalogs . Its primary functions include:
Creating custom business catalogs
Adding/removing catalog content (references to tiles and target mappings)
Copying catalogs (e.g., copy SAP standard catalog to customize)
Searching for launchpad content
Transporting catalogs [1]

2.Answer: d

Unit Test – Verifies that an individual program, function, or configuration element works as expected in isolation.
Business Process Test – Checks that complete end-to-end business workflows operate correctly across integrated modules.
User Acceptance Test (UAT) – Confirms, by end users, that the system meets business requirements before go-live.
Regression Test – Ensures that recent changes (e.g., upgrades, patches) haven’t broken existing functionality. specifically about re-testing to detect unintended impacts from changes.

3.Answer: b

4.Answer: a
The key points are migrating master data and a full historical data which will be possible only in brownfield or conversion approach.

5.Answer: d
The initial deployment starts by SAP Solution builder in Dev tier then you can use the Transport Management to move that to the higher tier.

6.Answer: a

7.Answer: d
a is tempting because it keeps the core untouched — but it can’t directly call unreleased ABAP objects or share LUW without APIs.
b delivers all technical needs but breaks “clean core” and upgrade safety — an instant long-term maintenance risk.
c satisfies low-code/no-code but fails the “deep ABAP integration” requirement.
d is the only one that ticks all boxes: same LUW, direct ABAP object reuse, upgrade-safe, and compliant with clean core via embedded Steampunk in-app extensions.

8.Answer: a, c
a is correct — Realize phase configuration is based on the signed backlog, and scope changes go through governance.
c is correct — performance tuning and regression testing are part of iterative cycles in Realize.
b is wrong — you don’t re-open full Fit-to-Standard in Realize, you handle gaps via change requests.
d is wrong — delaying performance issue resolution violates Activate’s iterative build/test principle.
e is wrong — skipping governance for new scope breaks methodology discipline.

9.Answer: b
SAP Store – to purchase SAP and partner solutions with licensing and pricing options.
SAP Discovery Centre – to access guided missions, service setup details, and cost estimations for SAP BTP services.
SAP Business Accelerator Hub – to browse and test APIs, integration content, and event definitions.
SAP Cloud ALM – to manage the application lifecycle with monitoring and documentation.

10.Answer: a, d
a correctly describes the SUM execution from target AAS and the automatic ASCS move dialog offering [1]
d accurately reflects that DMOVE2S4 uses standard DMO (not DMO with system move) and requires manual post-processing of filesystems and configurations 
b is incorrect because ASCS is NOT pre-installed; it's created during SUM execution
c is incorrect because SUM runs entirely from the target AAS, not from source PAS
This enhanced version tests deeper understanding of the technical architecture, timing of component installations, and post-migration considerations specific to DMOVE2S4 methodology.

11.Answer: a, c
a correctly describes the traditional PFCG approach with proper profile generation and user master record comparison
c accurately reflects using SU01 for user-to-role assignments with validity period management and user comparison process
b is incorrect - profiles should never be directly assigned to user master records without proper generation
d describes S/4HANA Cloud functionality, not Private Edition capabilities

12.Answer: b
A is incorrect: Migration Cockpit is included in S/4HANA licenses and supports comprehensive data migration beyond just manual staging table creation [1]
b is correct: Migration Cockpit is an integrated tool within S/4HANA that provides multiple migration approaches including staging tables and direct transfer methods, with built-in project management, simulation, validation, and execution capabilities for both master and transactional data [2]
c is incorrect: While source system add-ons may be required for specific scenarios (particularly for direct transfer from SAP ERP systems), Migration Cockpit supports various deployment options including Private Edition implementations and on-premise to private cloud migrations 
d is incorrect: Migration Cockpit supports comprehensive migration of both master data and transactional data with built-in capabilities, though third-party ETL tools can optionally be used to populate staging tables [3]

The Migration Cockpit provides integrated capabilities including migration object modeler (LTMOM), project management features, data validation, simulation modes, and flexible migration approaches specifically designed for S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition implementations 

13.Answer: b
a is incorrect because Private Edition does not use CBC (Central Business Configuration) - that's specific to Public Edition [2]
b is correct - Private Edition allows full classical ABAP development and uses SPRO-IMG transactions for configuration, providing extensive customization capabilities similar to On-Premise [1]
c is incorrect because Private Edition supports on-system development, unlike Public Edition which has more restrictions [2]
d is incorrect because Private Edition does not use the starter system approach - that's specific to Public Edition [3]

14.Answer: c
A is incorrect because SAP Best Practices should never be activated in client 000, which is only a reference client [1][2]
c is correct as it reflects the critical boundary conditions that must be followed when activating additional scope items or countries in SAP Best Practices [2]
b is incorrect because demo data activation is optional and can be added later, and demo data cannot be transported via standard mechanisms 
d is incorrect because the group currency cannot be changed once Best Practices activation starts and must be decided upfront [2][3]
Key Learning Points:
SAP Best Practices activation has strict boundary conditions for additional activations [2]
System upgrades and configuration changes to already activated countries can cause activation errors [2]
Group currency decisions are permanent once activation begins [3]
Best Practices should only be used in greenfield implementations [3]

15.Answer: a

https://training.sap.com/content/purchase-certification-attempts

entry.title: Re: How can i change SH in delivery Public Cloud
entry.content:
It is strictly not recommended to change the Ship-To in delivery. You can change in the sale order and create a delivery which is straight forward approach. On the other hand, if your business scenario requires alternate delivery addresses, consider using:

  • Partner function ZH (Alternate Ship-To) in the sales order
  • Customer-specific enhancements via In-App Extensibility (e.g., custom logic to validate or propose alternate addresses)
  • Delivery split logic based on Ship-To if multiple addresses are involved

For more details, SAP’s Delivery Setup Guide for Public Cloud explains the constraints and best practices.

entry.title: How to Send Email Notification to Multiple Supplier Contacts For Purchase Order
entry.content:
For Created/Changed/Canceled purchase order, email notification should be sent to multiple contacts from supplier, how to achieve this?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to Send Email Notification to Multiple Supplier C...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

There are two ways to achieve this:

1) When creating/changing/canceling a specific purchase order, click button You Can Also, select the option of edit output setting, in the pop-up window, in the section Email Settings, click Add Row to add email address. This output change only applies to this specific purchase order.

2) In the master data of supplier, select tab Communication, select sub tab Collaboration, select business document Purchase Order, in the below, select Add Row to add email address. This output change applies to all purchase order related to this supplier. 

Henry

SAP Support

entry.title: SAPで実現するサブスクリプション管理#2ーサブスクリプションビジネス成功の鍵：Q2Cソリューションとは
entry.content:
前回の記事では、サブスクリプションが今後のビジネス成長に欠かせないモデルである一方、多くの企業がITシステム面での課題に直面していることをお伝えしました。
では、こうした課題をどう解決し、サブスクリプションビジネスを軌道に乗せればよいのでしょうか。その答えとなるのが Q2C（Quote-to-Cash）ソリューション です。

今回は、サブスクリプションビジネスを支えるQ2Cソリューションの役割と、その中核を担う SAP Subscription Billing および SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud の機能について解説します。（その他のソリューションについては、後日紹介します。）

Q2C（Quote-to-Cash）とは？

Q2Cとは「見積もり（Quote）」から「入金・収益化（Cash）」まで、顧客取引の一連の流れを統合的に管理する仕組みです。
従来の「モノ売り」モデルでは比較的シンプルでしたが、サブスクリプションモデルでは次のように複雑なプロセスをシームレスにつなぐ必要があります。

  • 見積・案件管理: 顧客ごとに異なる料金プランや割引を適用し、見積を作成・管理
  • ソリューション販売: 受注・サービス・サブスクリプションを柔軟に組み合わせて提供
  • 請求: 定額・従量・使用量ベースを含む正確な請求書の発行
  • 入金・収益認識: 会計基準に基づいた売上計上を自動処理
  • 改善・拡張: 市場の変化に合わせて、バンドル構成や料金モデルを迅速に見直し

サブスクリプションビジネスの成功は、この複雑な一連の流れをいかに効率化・自動化できるかにかかっています。Q2Cソリューションは、その基盤を提供するものです

複雑なサブスクモデルを支える「SAP Subscription Billing＋S/4HANA Public Cloud」

SAP Subscription Billingは、多様なサブスクリプションモデルに対応したQ2Cプロセスを支援するソリューションです。
特にSAP S/4HANA Public Cloudと連携することで、フロントからバックエンドまで一貫した業務プロセスを構築し、前回の記事で挙げた課題を包括的に解決します。

課題1：複雑な料金モデルの管理

  • 解決策: Webベースの直感的なUIで、定額制・従量制・階層制などの複雑な料金体系を柔軟に設定可能。特別なプログラミングは不要で、セールス担当者自身が新しい料金プランを作成できます。

課題2：契約ライフサイクル管理の煩雑さ

  • 解決策: 契約開始・一時停止・変更・解約までを自動管理。顧客リクエストに応じて契約を変更しても、新料金が自動適用されるため、手作業の負担やミスを削減します。

課題3：正確かつ迅速な請求処理

  • 解決策: 契約情報と利用データをリアルタイムで連携し、自動で料金計算。月末の煩雑な処理を省き、正確な請求書をタイムリーに発行できます。

課題4：システム間連携の難しさ

  • 解決策: Subscription BillingはS/4HANA Public Cloudと標準シナリオでシームレスに統合可能です。受注処理から会計処理・収益認識・決済までデータを一元管理でき、プロセス全体をリアルタイムで可視化可能。さらに、顧客や製品のマスタデータも容易に統合できるため、全社的なデータ整合性を確保できます。

【実際の画面イメージ】

まとめ

サブスクリプションビジネスの成功は、顧客に提供する価値だけでなく、それを支える堅牢な業務基盤にかかっています。
Q2Cソリューション、とりわけ SAP Subscription BillingとSAP S/4HANA Public Cloudの連携 は、複雑なサブスクモデルを効率的に運用し、ビジネスをスケールさせるための強力な手段です。

次回は、実際にこれらのソリューションを導入した企業事例を通じて、具体的な効果やメリットを紹介します。
サブスクリプションモデルの導入・拡大をご検討中の方は、ぜひご期待ください。

共同著者：@masanobu

entry.title: Release Navigator for SAP BTP - What's New in Q3 2025
entry.content:
The Release Navigator for SAP BTP continues to evolve and expand, offering our customers improved resources and streamlined access to product updates.

With the Q3 2025 update, we ensured all content is up-to-date and we are excited to announce the addition of a new product page for SAP Customer Data Solutions as well as some cosmetic UI updates. Read more about the details in this blog post.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Collaborating closely with SAP BTP experts, we've expanded the release coverage by introducing 11 new product pages. These pages compile links to all available release information, such as schedules, pre- and post-release communications, blogs, and more:

  • SAP Customer Data Solutions, including
    • SAP Customer Data Cloud / SAP Customer Identity and Access Management
    • SAP Customer Data Platform

Read on to see what you can find on this new page.

SAP Customer Data Solutions

This page contains specific resources for SAP Customer Identity and Access Management, SAP Customer Data Platform, as well as release resources relevant across different SAP Customer Data Solutions. Here’s a list of all you can find on this page:

  • SAP Customer Identity and Access Management (CDC)
    • Roadmap Explorer: Upcoming Innovations
    • What’s New Viewer: Release Notes
    • Customer Influence Campaign
    • SAP Community Tag
  • SAP Customer Data Platform
    • Roadmap Explorer: Upcoming Innovations
    • What’s New Viewer: Release Notes
    • Customer Influence Campaign
    • SAP Community Tag
  • General Customer Data Solutions Resources
    • SAP BTP Newsletter
    • Enablement Webcasts
    • Subscription link to Cloud Availability Center

Please Note: This page has previously been available via the Release Navigator for Customer Experience. Adding this page to the Release Navigator for SAP BTP reflects the move of SAP Customer Data Solutions from the Customer Experience area to SAP BTP. The page in the Release Navigator for Customer Experience will stay online until the beginning of Q4 2025 for everyone to take note and switch out their potential bookmarks or saved links. After that, only the page within the Release Navigator for SAP BTP will remain available.

Check it out.

 

 

With this last round of updates, we added new visual elements to all release navigators. The UI updates in the Release Navigator for SAP BTP do not affect functionality or performance and are strictly cosmetical.

On the home page also known as the Product Specific page, you will notice that our Welcome and Release Calendar cards have received a facelift for a fresher look and feel. 

On all pages where you can open informational text boxes by hovering over the lightbulb icon, you will see a slight update to the design of these boxes. Content and functionality remain the same. 

As a reminder: These pop-up boxes show up on every page with a lightbulb icon at the top and may be moved around on the page or closed once you are done reading them.

 

 

For centralized information regarding the release of new features for SAP BTP products and services, consult the Consolidated Release Schedule for SAP BTP.

Regarding the Release Navigator updates, refer to this update plan:

*Disclaimer: The schedule is subject to alterations without notice, including potential delays or the integration of changes in subsequent update windows. It doesn't establish a commitment, promise, or legal duty to deliver any material, code, or functionality. Looking into the remaining quarters of 2025, updates will focus on quarterly content maintenance and a steady extension of product coverage. No substantial UI updates are planned for the time being.

 

 

The Readiness@Scale team within SAP Enterprise Support is driven to ensure release readiness across the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio. Our mission is to empower SAP customers to effectively adopt and utilize innovations.

If you have feedback or specific requests for content within the release navigator, feel free to contact us.

Don't forget to explore our team’s blogs tagged under Readiness@Scale.

Happy navigating!

Readiness@Scale  
SAP Enterprise Support

entry.title: Re: [ABAP 7.4] : What is the new program to change released task to unreleased ?
entry.content:
The note mentioned 3132029 cannot be accessed via OSS anymore.... But:

On SolMan it should be possible to delete the ChaRM there (leaving an orhpaned TR in the connected SAP system with a released task). Via SE16, debug to EDIT or DELETE mode change of E070 it should be possible to:

  1. Delete the Transport of Copies task
  2. Change the status of the released task from R (released) to D (changes possible)

After that, SE01 or SE10 should be sufficient to delete the request/task as per usual if the task would not have been released before.

entry.title: Re: Reconciliation Account selection in "Create Supplier...
entry.content:
Hello @Kazuhiro_F 

Thank you for sharing the screenshots. I understand why there was confusion.

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the reconciliation account for supplier invoices is typically derived from the supplier master data and cannot be modified during the invoice posting process. The behaviour you noticed in one system, where you can select the reconciliation account manually, usually happens under these circumstances

  • The supplier is set up as a one-time vendor account group that permits reconciliation account entry.
  • The reconciliation account is not kept in the supplier master, leaving the field blank when posting.
  • Field status configuration through SSCUI 150001 or related settings permits optional entry.

For standard suppliers, it is best practice to assign a fixed reconciliation account in the master data to ensure accurate reconciliation between the subledger and general ledger. Editable reconciliation accounts should be used only in one-time vendor situations.

I recommend examining the supplier account group and reconciliation account configurations in both systems to understand why editing is allowed in one but not the other.

SAP Help Portal – Create Supplier Invoice (F0859)

SAP Help Portal – Supplier Master Data and Reconciliation Accounts

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: To close old STOs with open archived OBDs that have b...
entry.content:
Some of the workarounds when OBDs are archived

1. Unarchive Temporarily (if policy allows).
If your organization permits it, you can temporarily reload the archived delivery using transaction SARI or via Archive Information System. Once restored, you can reverse PGI using VL09, adjust the STO accordingly. After corrections, the delivery can be re-archived. This requires coordination with your BASIS team and may not be feasible in tightly controlled environments.

2. Manual Closure via ME22N
If reversal isn’t possible, you can manually set the “Delivery Completed” indicator in ME22N for the STO line item. This tells the system that no further deliveries or GRs are expected. You may also need to adjust the open quantity to match the delivered quantity if the system blocks the flag due to mismatch.

3. Custom Program or BAPI
Some companies develop a custom report or BAPI-based tool to mass-close STOs with archived deliveries. These tools bypass standard checks and update the delivery completion flag or final delivery status directly in the backend.

4. Accounting Adjustments
If the goods were never received and cannot be reversed, consider posting a manual write-off to a loss account or cost center. This is often done via MB1A with movement type 551 (scrapping) or similar.

entry.title: Budget excededing issue

Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Service contract determination on service orders
entry.content:
Hello,

On the payload for the service order, on item level, you can include the field SrvcContrDetnIsSpprsd, it indicates that the service contract determination is suppressed in the service order item. Check the documentation Service Order Items | SAP Help Portal

It's also possible to configure the service contract determination through this configuration activity: 'Specify Contract Determination Option for Trans. Types' (ID: 103686).

Kind regards.

entry.title: Re: BAdI is internal SAP; implementation in customer namespace not allowed
entry.content:
• You cannot implement BADI in Z: it is blocked by design.

  • Recommended solution: find a released BAdI for Batch Management via SE18.

  • If not available: use an enhancement point in the standard (with caution).

entry.title: Re: Hard currency values as realtime posting in asset dep...
entry.content:
Dear Ronaldo

No, activating hard currency real-time posting for ledger L1 only will not affect other ledgers (0L, T1) as long as depreciation areas are carefully mapped per ledger group. The only effect is in ACDOCA entries and reporting, where you will see explicit TRY postings for L1.

Have you tried the following?

In FI-AA IMG:
SPRO → Financial Accounting → Asset Accounting → Valuation → Currencies → Specify Depreciation Areas for Foreign Currencies

Create a depreciation area linked to Hard Currency (40).

Set it as real-time posting.

Assign it to ledger group L1 only.

In Depreciation Area → Ledger Assignment:

Ensure hard currency depreciation area is not assigned to 0L and T1.

Best regards
