entry.title: Re: S/4 Hana Extensibility Service Instance
entry.content:
Hello @Dipto_Arafat 

The S/4HANA Public Cloud service binding is necessary, as it provides your BTP app with trusted endpoints and credentials for a secure connection to SAP S/4HANA Cloud. While the XSUAA binding secures your app's users, the S4-HANA Public Cloud binding facilitates system-to-system integration through API calls and events. The Destination service stores the runtime connection details used by your code.

For side-by-side extension using TypeScript and SAP Cloud SDK, the process is as follows:

  1. Create a communication arrangement in S/4HANA Cloud.
  2. Create and bind S4 HANA Cloud, XSUAA, and Destination services in BTP.
  3. Configure a Destination to the S/4HANA API.
  4. Download the EDMX from SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  5. Use Cloud SDK to generate TypeScript client code.
  6. In your app, call the API via the generated client — the SDK reads the Destination at runtime.

Brief

  • XSUAA → secures the app (users).
  • s4-hana-cloud → secures the S/4HANA Cloud link.
  • Destination → holds API endpoint/auth for runtime use.

Check below SAP documentation

  • SAP Cloud SDK for JavaScript/TypeScript
  • Learning Journey – Develop Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK
  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: FMS In Good Issue
entry.content:
Hi @user2001 ,

I understand your pain. The hardcoded value FMS is not a dynamic choice, indeed. I've used user-defined tables for such purposes many times, and I think it is the best approach without going further with coding. So you would have a table where all GL to CC mapping is kept, and your FMS would look up values on this table, which streamlines maintenance a lot.

Regarding SAP's behaviour, have a look at how GLs are set up in the Chart of Accounts. When an account is of the type "other", it's understood as a Balance Sheet GL (BS), where typically there is no cost assignment, although you may keep a GL in the BS structure of your CoA and set it up as "Expense" or "Sales", which basically tells SAP you want to enable cost assignment. This is a business decision and must be studied to understand the impacts.

 

Either way, when you call an GL in the document, SAP will try to get the CC from the CoA setup. For example, if in your case, 5001014 GL has ABC-1234 defaulted to one cost dimension, selecting this account will make SAP enforce this default value and fetch ABC-1234. If there is no CC default, it will enforce NULL (no value), that's why your field gets emptied after the FMS is triggered, as the GL gets populated. 

I hope it makes sense.


BR,
Felipe

entry.title: SAP Community Voice: Site Improvements, New Badges, and Hot Content
entry.content:
If you’re a What’s New regular, you know we’ve been busy since our last newsletter edition on August 15. We’ve launched new progression badge sets (with more coming in September), made several site improvements, and announced a redesign pilot for blog posts.

If you missed those updates, we summarize them for your convenience below. We also highlight popular blog posts from SAP and non-SAP members, introduce new groups and topic pages, and cover upcoming events.

Read on to learn more!

 

Featured Content

 

ABAP Extensibility Guide – Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud

SAP’s @OlgaDolinskaja gives a breakdown of new clean-core extensibility guidance and explains how the ABAP extensibility guide has been updated with guidelines that align with and support the clean-core level concept for the classification of custom extensions. You won’t want to miss this post and its lively thread! 

Read the blog post

 

Introducing the New AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite

@Punith_Oswal, one of our SAP Champions, has a question for you: Have you ever wished that your iFlow could talk to ChatGPT? If you answered yes, you’ll want to take some time out of your day to read this post. And if you answered no, I still feel pretty positive you’ll enjoy this contribution.

Read the blog post

 

New Series: SAP UX Q3/2025 Updates

A new series from SAP’s @ThomasReiss provides an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering the whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, and SAP SuccessFactors, as well as detailing innovations in SAP’s UI technologies for building great UX.

Start with the first post, which contains links to the entire series

 

SAP Cloud Application Programming Model with Local App Previews

I’m happy to see our SAP Champions have been so active with their blogging this month! @MioYasutake has written a short blog post detailing experiences while trying out virtual endpoints with SAP Cloud Application Programming Model with Node.js. The post covers findings while testing local previews.

Read the blog post

 

Community News

 

Badges, Badges, and More Badges!

Long-time SAP Community members may remember the days when they could earn sets of badges for ongoing positive contributions. Well, we’ve brought these progression badges back! This week, we rolled out four new badges based on the number of kudos received. Last week we assigned badges for providing solutions to questions. And there are more badges coming in the weeks ahead. With these badges, we’re once again recognizing active members and encouraging everyone to make our community a better place by participating more frequently. Make sure to subscribe to What’s New so you won’t miss more badge announcements next month!

 

New Features: Dark Mode (Beta) and Events Listings

A beta version of dark mode is available for SAP Community, and our events listings now include additional filtering options that make it easier for you to find activities of interest to you. You can learn more about these two new features in this post. Experiment with dark mode/light mode to see which presentation works best for you, and try out the various new event filters to find educational and social get-togethers in your area that appeal to you.

 

Your Feedback Wanted for New Design Pilot

We’re currently running a pilot to test a new layout for blog posts that removes widgets and white space from the right column – based on a feature request from members who asked us to improve the readability of these pages. You can learn more about this pilot in this post, and we’re inviting members to share their opinions in the comments there. The pilot concludes on Tuesday, September 23, so please leave your input there before then.

 

New Location Groups Now Available

We’ve launched (or renamed) three location groups. Our Brazilian members continue to expand our groups in the Americas – with the recent addition of Joinville. Over in the Europe section, the former ’s-Hertogenbosch group has switched its name to The Netherlands to accommodate more members in that country. Elsewhere in Europe, we’ve introduced the Düsseldorf-Köln group to bring together members from those cities. If you’re from one of these areas, you’ll want to join the corresponding group so you can connect with members close to you.

 

Upcoming Events

 

Meet SAP TechEd Community Speaker Marla Alschweiki

@TammyPowlas, part of our SAP Mentors program, has referred to the upcoming SAP TechEd event as a family reunion, and so it’s no surprise she’s showing familial-type support for another SAP Mentor, @Marla-Schwaiki (whom we mentioned in the last edition of SAP Community Voice). In this post, Tammy explains why you should attend Marla’s community talk in Berlin. We love seeing members supporting members, so if you’re planning to attend SAP TechEd, please make sure to include Marla’s session in your schedule.

 

Find Meetup Events in Your Region

In the last two SAP Community Voice newsletters, we’ve focused on SAP CodeJam events, but as explained earlier in this edition, our events listings have been expanded to include filters for finding a variety of local activities. Therefore, I’d like to use this edition to draw attention to meetups (also known as SAP Stammtisch events in Germany) in September. Next month, you can socialize with members in Wien (Austria), Gurugram (India), Casablanca (Morocco), Dortmund (Germany), Cyprus (Greece), Brussels (Belgium), Warsaw (Poland), Lingen (Germany), Bamberg (Germany), Hamburg (Germany), Porto (Portugal), Rio Grande do Sul (Brazil), and Luzern (Switzerland). You can find a full list of events here. Make sure to register for an event near you!

entry.title: Making Sense of Sales Org Structures in SAP: Sales, Sales Org, Sales Office, and Sales Group
entry.content:
When you first look at sales structures in SAP, the terms can feel like they’re all saying the same thing. Sales Org, Sales Office, Sales Group, Sales Unit—it’s easy to get lost. Let’s break it down in a way that actually makes sense.

1. Sales Org, Sales Office, Sales Group – the classics
Think of these as the traditional building blocks. They’ve been around in ERP and S/4 forever, and they have specific meanings:

  • Sales Organization: The top level. Usually tied to a country or a large region, like “Germany Sales Org.” It’s also important in transactions (pricing, master data, sales orders, etc.).

  • Sales Office: A sub-level, often representing a physical office, like “Berlin Sales Office.”

  • Sales Group: Even more granular, like “North Berlin Sales Group” inside that office.

These units are embedded into the system. They show up in transactions, master data, and user assignments. If a sales rep is tied to a Sales Group, that info automatically flows into quotes, orders, and reporting.

2. Sales Unit – the flexible layer
Now here’s the modern twist: Sales Unit is like a flexible overlay that lets you model your structure more creatively. It’s not bound by the strict definitions of Org, Office, or Group.

Why use it?

  • You want reporting across multiple orgs (e.g., “Europe Sales” across five countries).

  • You want to add dimensions that aren’t in your backend (e.g., splitting one office into “Internet Sales” vs. “Direct Sales”).

  • You want to restructure without touching the ERP backbone.

In short: Sales Units let you go beyond the rigid ERP structure.

3. How they work together
Here’s the simplest way to think of it:

  • Sales Org / Office / Group = specific, traditional sales units that matter for master and transaction data.

  • Sales Unit = the superset that gives you finer granularity and flexibility.

When you assign a user to a Sales Unit and they create a sales document (like a quote), the system knows the hierarchy. It pulls in the related Sales Group, Office, and Org automatically.

So what’s the takeaway?

  • If you’re defining legal and transactional structures, stick to Sales Org, Office, and Group.

  • If you’re defining reporting and flexible structures, use Sales Units.

That’s it. No need to overcomplicate. Think of Sales Units as your way to model the real-world sales structure without being trapped by backend constraints.

entry.title: Re: PGI and PGR in Advanced Returns Management (ARM)
entry.content:
Why PGI works differently in ARM is because, in classic returns, the system treats the SD-FC (Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge) order as a standalone replenishment. You can upload stock directly to the SD-FC sales order item and execute PGI without issue.

But in ARM, the SD-FC order is logistically and financially linked to the original return order. This linkage is managed through the follow-up activity and returns document flow, which changes how inventory is tracked and consumed.

What is happening behind the scenes is when you create a return order in ARM, the returned goods are received into blocked stock (typically via movement type 653). The system tracks this blocked stock against the return sales order and item, not the SD-FC order. When you create the SD-FC order, it inherits the reference to the return order. But the system expects the PGI to consume stock from the return order, not from a fresh upload to the SD-FC order. So when you upload stock against the SD-FC order directly, the system doesn’t recognize it as valid for PGI—because it’s not part of the ARM-managed return flow.

What you can do is if you want PGI to work smoothly in ARM:

  • Always upload or adjust stock against the return order and item.
  • Ensure the follow-up activity in the ARM return order is correctly set to “Subsequent Delivery Free of Charge.”
  • Use transaction MSR_INSPWH if inspection is involved, to release stock from blocked to unrestricted before PGI.
